lessons.title: Seeing through time: A puzzling history of optics
lessons.preface: Discover the secrets printed on the US dollar bill using a water drop-lens, and explore lens innovations throughout history with a timeline puzzle sort.

lessons.title: What's a lens? Bending light for sight
lessons.preface: Learn how lenses bend light through an interactive video, and brainstorm new materials to design a sight-correcting lens.

lessons.title: What is light? Making waves
lessons.preface: Illustrate the anatomy of a wave by linking together as a human wave-medium to transmit waves with different amplitudes and frequencies. Then, investigate the full spectrum of light waves with a ranking game.

lessons.title: Communicating with light: A message to Mars
lessons.preface: Expand on the advanced properties of light. Then design a code that uses waves to send a message to Mars!

lesson.lsnTitle: Seeing through time: A puzzling history of optics
lesson.lsnPreface: Discover the secrets printed on the US dollar bill using a water drop-lens, and explore lens innovations throughout history with a timeline puzzle sort.
lesson.learningObj: Students will demonstrate an engineering mindset, using lenses to solve problems through magnification or focusing

lsnPrep.prepDetails: Print copies of the timeline puzzle sort ([➚ Magnification Technologies Timeline Puzzle](https://docs.google.com/presentation/d/18D0tqNx2flXrTFb1iFINHORV_diTpKMCWTbpSPGL8iU)).

steps.StepQuickDescription: Examine a dollar bill first with bare eyes, then with the magnification of a small water droplet.
steps.StepDetails: Directions and discussion prompts are included in the presentation slides.

steps.StepQuickDescription: Read about magnifying devices throughout history and determine when they were invented.
steps.StepDetails: Students will work in small groups to sort the cards in the handout: [➚ Magnification Technologies Timeline Puzzle](https://docs.google.com/presentation/d/18D0tqNx2flXrTFb1iFINHORV_diTpKMCWTbpSPGL8iU)

steps.StepQuickDescription: Watch the first part of [▶ Engineering with Light: 2000 Years of Innovation](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=DREGrkSnZ2g) to reveal more secrets of the dollar bill, as well as the magnification timeline answers!
Students can correct their timeline if necessary, and are encouraged to look for lenses out in the world after class.

lsnExt.itemDescription: Have students investigate other interesting facets of different dollar denominations using their liquid lenses.

lesson.lsnTitle: What's a lens? Bending light for sight
lesson.lsnPreface: Learn how lenses bend light through an interactive video, and brainstorm new materials to design a sight-correcting lens.
learningObj: Students will understand wave properties of light.
Students will interpret data to validate how the properties of waves can be used to transmit information.

lsnPrep.prepDetails: Print student worksheets ([➚ Seeing Through Time worksheet](https://docs.google.com/document/d/1lGF3DM_G_NVjIw7AFz9Xtfxa3LFchEY3GU2b_rQzSHI/edit)).

steps.StepQuickDescription: Watch a video about the history and science of lenses and follow along on the student worksheet.
steps.StepDetails: The "What Are Lenses?" video ([▶ Engineering with Light: 2000 Years of Innovation](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=DREGrkSnZ2g)) is embedded in the presentation slides with break points for discussion and reflection questions. Students can follow along with the discussion by taking notes on their worksheet: [➚ Seeing Through Time worksheet](https://docs.google.com/document/d/1lGF3DM_G_NVjIw7AFz9Xtfxa3LFchEY3GU2b_rQzSHI/edit).
steps.Vocab:
- **photonics:** The study of manipulating light.
- **lens:** A piece of material which is transparent and curved, useful for bending light.
- **convex:** A lens which curves outward on at least one side.
- **concave:** A lens which curves inward (creating a shallow "cave") on at least one side.
- **focal point:** The point at which light rays converge after passing through a lens.

steps.StepQuickDescription: Extend the knowledge from the lesson to determine how vision should be corrected.
steps.StepDetails: Students discuss in groups to determine what kind of glasses should go to far- or nearsighted people, recording the answers on their worksheets. They check their answer and learn more about corrective eyeware with this video: [▶ How Glasses Work to Correct Vision](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=1vlojCoFrTw).
steps.Vocab:
- **farsighted:** The focal point of the eye falls behind the retina.
- **nearsighted:** The focal point of the eye falls in front of the retina.
steps.VariantNotes: Less advanced students (e.g. G6-7) might not be prepared for these challenge questions.

steps.StepQuickDescription: Students imagine themselves as optical engineers to consider the design challenges associated with making lenses.
steps.StepDetails: In the space provided on their worksheets ([➚ Seeing Through Time worksheet](https://docs.google.com/document/d/1lGF3DM_G_NVjIw7AFz9Xtfxa3LFchEY3GU2b_rQzSHI/edit)) students answer several reflection questions related to lens design and optical engineering.

steps.StepQuickDescription: Students ensure they've completed their worksheets.
steps.StepDetails: If needed, students can watch the video again at home to double check their answers.

lsnExt.itemDescription: Advanced students (e.g. G8-9) can explore the geometry of light, lenses, and mirrors using this interactive simulation.

lesson.lsnPreface: Illustrate the anatomy of a wave by linking together as a human wave-medium to transmit waves with different amplitudes and frequencies. Then, investigate the full spectrum of light waves with a ranking game.
lesson.learningObj: Students will understand that light travels differently through various media, depending on the medium's index of refraction.

lsnPrep.prepDetails: Print student worksheets ([➚ What is Light Worksheet](https://docs.google.com/document/d/1oKBFUmXcudtQE21y59Q1sDxxEdoMGWW9OIz7MUcLNFI/edit?usp=drive_link))

steps.StepQuickDescription: A couple quick questions to get students thinking about waves.
Linking their arms together, students send messages across the room by transferring a wave!
steps.StepDetails: Students practice creating waves with various amplitudes and frequencies. Detailed instructions are in the teacher key.

steps.StepQuickDescription: It's time to learn about the parts that make up a wave.
steps.StepDetails: The wave activity provides an introduction to waves, defining the pieces of a wave through cooperative body movement. Students follow along by taking notes on their worksheet ([➚ What is Light Worksheet](https://docs.google.com/document/d/1oKBFUmXcudtQE21y59Q1sDxxEdoMGWW9OIz7MUcLNFI/edit?usp=drive_link)).
steps.Vocab:
- **wave:** a repeating pattern that transfers energy from one place to another.
- **amplitude:** the height of a wave.
- **frequency:** the number of complete waves that travels per second.

steps.StepQuickDescription: Students rank how certain they are that a phenomenon is or is not light. Then we check in with Dr. Tom Folland via video ([▶ What is Light?](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Pfgh29tQZlk)) to hear how he defines light.
steps.StepDetails: The student worksheet ([➚ What is Light Worksheet](https://docs.google.com/document/d/1oKBFUmXcudtQE21y59Q1sDxxEdoMGWW9OIz7MUcLNFI/edit?usp=drive_link)) has space for students to rank how certain they are about whether or not a light-candidate is light, as well as room to notice similarities or surprises.
steps.Vocab: - **light:** electromagnetic radiation which includes the visible spectrum, as well as radio waves, infrared heat, x-rays, and more.

steps.StepTitle: What is Light? with Dr. Tom Folland
steps.StepQuickDescription: Check in with Dr. Tom Folland via video ([▶ What is Light?](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Pfgh29tQZlk)) to hear how he defines light.
The presentation uses the Crab Nebula as an example of light radiated at different frequencies.

lsnExt.itemTitle: Waves or Particles? The Double Slit Experiment
lsnExt.itemDescription: Check out this video to see what the average adult knows about light. The Double Slit Experiment introduces students to the central questions of quantum mechanics.
Explore videos like this one to dig further into relevant waves like Wifi!

Hedy Lamarr was a famous actress and inventor who paved the wave for modern-day technologies such as Wifi and Bluetooth. Check out this lesson plan (G6-8) made by the Women's History Museum to learn more about her contributions to science.

lesson.lsnTitle: Communicating with light: A message to Mars
lesson.lsnPreface: Expand on the advanced properties of light. Then design a code that uses waves to send a message to Mars!

lsnPrep.prepDetails: Print student worksheets ([➚ Communicating with Light Worksheet](https://docs.google.com/document/d/1kNB-kO3TCaewh8QpAUzDbh_uJykdx4I3PRQKBO-4yRw/edit))

steps.StepQuickDescription: Students quickly share out what they learned about light yesterday.
The presentation gives a short overview of more advanced properties of light.
steps.Vocab:
- **photon:** a particle of light
- **electromagnetic fields:** an invisible field all around us, which oscillates to create light

steps.StepQuickDescription: The fastest way to send a message to Mars is by using light waves-- but how can information be encoded in them?
steps.StepDetails: Students work together to design a code with three simple messages. The activity culminates in sending the secret messages from one side of the room to the other. Detailed instructions for this activity are in the teacher worksheet.

steps.StepQuickDescription: To review wave anatomy, we look at radios as a practical application of encoding and decoding wave signals.
steps.StepDetails: From Morse code, to AM and FM radio, all the way to WiFi and Bluetooth, encoding messages in light has helped us send information faster and farther than ever before. With a nod to actress-inventor Hedy Lamarr, and technology we use every day, this wrap up discussion highlights the prevalence of light-communication all around us.

steps.StepQuickDescription: Lightning review of lessons 3 and 4, and a debrief of the photonics unit.

lsnExt.itemDescription: Have your students calculate the wavelength, frequency and speed of radio waves with this problem set.
